questions.question_text: Identify three reasons for using a recovery catalog with Recovery Manager (RMAN).

choices.C: to maintain a backup for an indefinite period of time by using the KEEP FOREVER clause
choices.E: to automatically delete obsolete backups after a specified period of time
choices.A: to store backup information of multiple databases in one place
choices.B: to restrict the amount of space that is used by backups
choices.D: to store RMAN scripts that are available to any RMAN client that can connect to target databasesregistered in the recovery catalog

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true regarding Oracle Data Pump?

discussion.content: Answer E is also correct; dbms_metadata is also part of Oracle DataPump; Doc: https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/SUTIL/GUID-47B26B0B-3C95-4182-ACDF-2EEDD577FC9E.htm#SUTIL801

choices.E: EXPDP and IMPDP use the procedures provided by DBMS_METADATA to execute export and import commands.
choices.D: Oracle Data Pump imports can be done from the export files generated in the Original Export Utility.
choices.A: EXPDP and IMPDP are the client components of Oracle Data Pump.
choices.C: Oracle Data Pump export and import operations can be performed only by users with the SYSDBA privilege.
choices.B: DBMS_DATAPUMP PL/SQL packages can be used independently of the Data Pump clients.

questions.question_text: Which two statements are true about making RMAN image copies of a database?

choices.E: They can be made only when the database is running in ARCHIVELOG mode.
choices.D: They consist of all used an unused blocks in the data files.
choices.B: The can be made only when the database is running in NOARCHIVELOG mode.
choices.A: The can only be written to disk.
choices.C: They can be made only when the database is in MOUNT state.

questions.answer_description:
An image copy can be written only to disk.
An image copy is the same as datafiles. The disadvantage of image copy backup mode is that it occupies much space and does not skip unused data blocks.
References:
http://www.dba-oracle.com/t_rman_10_image_copies.htm

comments.content: Yes correct and "TO COPY" can only be saved in disk

discussion.content:
The answer is B.
When the connected catalog DB version is lower than the import catalog DB, then you should upgrade the version to match it.
However in this question the connected DB version is higher than the import DB there is no problem. Also see Q.200 and you will know why A is not the answer.
In addition in the reference "Stored scripts are either global or local. It is possible for global scripts, but not local scripts, to have name conflicts during import because the destination schema contains an object with the same name. In this case, RMAN renames the global script name to COPY OF script_name. For example, RMAN renames bp_cmd to COPY OF bp_cmd."
So the recommended answer is correct.
REF:https://docs.oracle.com/database/121/RCMRF/rcmsynta026.htm#RCMRF198
The version of the source recovery catalog schema must be equal to the current version of the destination recovery catalog schema. If they are not equal, then upgrade the schemas to the same version.

questions.question_text:
The CATDBI2c database contains an Oracle Database 12c catalog schema owned by the rc12c user.
The CATDB11 database contains an Oracle Database l1g catalog schema owned by the RCII user.
A database with DBID=1423241 is registered in the CATDB11 catalog. Both the recovery catalog databases are open.
In the CATDB12c database, you execute the commands:
//IMG//

What is the outcome of the import?

choices.C: It succeeds but the database is not automatically registered in the RC12c catalog.
choices.A: It fails because the target database and recovery catalog database are of different versions.
choices.D: It fails because RMAN is not connected to the target database with DBID=1423241.
choices.B: It succeeds and all global scripts in the RC11 catalog that have the same name as existing global scripts in the RC12C catalog are automatically renamed.

choices.C: It updates the alert log file with the location and contents of the control file.
choices.D: It creates a binary backup of the control file.
choices.A: It creates a copy of the control file and stores it in the location specified in the diagnostic_dest initialization parameter.
choices.B: It creates a file that contains the SQL statement, which is required to re-create the control file.
